qas.question: What is the short term goal of open market operations?

answers.text: achieve a specific short-term interest rate target

qas.question: What does the Federal Reserve target?
What is the federal funds rate?

answers.text: the rate at which member banks lend to one another overnight

qas.question: What is the cajoling of certain market players to achieve specified outcomes also known as?

answers.text: talking monetary policy with the market

plausible_answers.text: achieve a specific short-term interest rate target

qas.question: What is the short term goal of open mouth operatioins?
What do open mouth operations target?

plausible_answers.text: the rate at which member banks lend to one another overnight

qas.question: What is the federal specified outcome?
What is the cajoling of certain market players to achieve member bank rates also known as?

plausible_answers.text: talking monetary policy with the market

qas.question: What does gold rate exchange mean?

context: Usually, the short-term goal of open market operations is to <a0_0><b5_0>achieve a specific short-term interest rate target<b5_0/><a0_0/>. In other instances, monetary policy might instead entail the targeting of a specific exchange rate relative to some foreign currency or else relative to gold. For example, in the case of the United States the Federal Reserve targets the <a1_0><b6_0>federal funds rate<b6_0/><a1_0/>, <a2_0><b7_0>the rate at which member banks lend to one another overnight<b7_0/><a2_0/>. The other primary means of conducting monetary policy include: (i) Discount window lending (as lender of last resort); (ii) Fractional deposit lending (changes in the reserve requirement); (iii) <a3_0><b8_0>Moral suasion<b8_0/><a3_0/> (cajoling certain market players to achieve specified outcomes); (iv) "Open mouth operations" (<a4_0><b9_0>talking monetary policy with the market<b9_0/><a4_0/>).
